Award.AwardTitle: Fabrication of Large-Area and Large-Bandgap Semiconducting Graphene Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The overarching goal of this project is to learn how to open up a technologically relevant bandgap in graphene via top-down nanopatterning and nanomanufacturing approaches that can be scaled to large-areas. Our specific objectives are to: (1) tailor and reduce nanopattern- size and shape to achieve larger bandgaps > 0.5 eV; (2) learn how to scale to ~5x5 cm2 or larger ?wafers? of semiconducting graphene; (3) control the atomic functionalization of graphene edges which become increasingly important as feature-size is reduced; and (4) demonstrate proof-of-principal wafer-wide arrays of semiconducting graphene electronic devices. Our approach for nanomanufacturing large bandgap graphene in a scalable fashion will be to employ self-directed lithographic templates. The templates will be based on block copolymers and small molecules that will be tailored to self-assemble on graphene with unprecedented patterning resolution and will be used in conjunction with controlled top-down patterning to control the electronic behaviors of graphene.

Broader significant and importance: Graphene has received substantial attention recently because of its exceptional electronic, optical, mechanical, and thermal properties. While unpatterned graphene is not a semiconductor, nanopatterned graphene acts like one, meaning that its electrical conductivity can be switched ?ON? and ?OFF?. This has spurred excitement for semiconducting graphene in electronics, infrared optoelectronics and photonics, biosensing, and solar energy harvesting in hopes of exploiting graphene?s exceptional properties for these applications. The proposed research will culminate in novel nanomanufacturing processes that will enable the fabrication of large-area ?wafers? of technologically relevant semiconducting graphene. The semiconducting graphene ?wafers? will be transformative and powerful materials platforms for launching a wide range of next-generation applications based on carbon nanotechnology. The principal investigators will also mentor undergraduate and under-represented students in research and participate in a course at UW-Madison designed to allow bench scientists and science communicators to develop and use effective strategies for communicating with the general public about science and technology, particularly about nanotechnology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

This project advanced the manufacturing of a novel form of graphene, called nanoperforated graphene that is perforated by a regular array of nanometer-scale holes. Graphene is an ultrathin material that is comprised of a single layer of carbon atoms. It is one of the best conductors of electricity that has ever been discovered. Moreover, it is incredibly strong for its size. Perforating graphene with tightly packed, nanometer-scale holes brings new functionality to graphene. Nanoperforated graphene promises to have impact in a number of future applications, for example in faster, more energy-efficient consumer electronic devices; new types of biomedical sensors; and energy-efficient water desalination and reclamation membranes. One of the largest roadblocks to developing this material for real-world applications has been its manufacturing. Many of the functionalities that nanoperforated graphene promises only occur when the feature sizes are less than 10 nanometers (nm) and are tightly packed together. However, it is difficult to achieve this high resolution and fidelity during a large-area manufacturing process.

At the project onset, we had discovered a robust approach for nanopatterning graphene that had the potential to simultaneously achieve both excellent resolution and scalability that was based on an adaptation of block copolymer (BCP) lithography. In general, BCP lithography can be facilely scaled to batch-process multiple, large-area substrates in parallel while achieving the high-fidelity patterning of exceptionally small features that are less than 10 nm. When a thin film of BCPs is deposited onto a specially tuned substrate, the different components of the BCPs separate from one-another to automatically form self-assembled patterns like those shown in the accompanying images. These patterns can have sub-10 nm dimensions and act as a stencil to lithographically transfer the patterns into the graphene in combination with the use of etchants.

Over the course of this project, we made several advances in the use of BCPs to form nanoperforated graphene. Highlights include:

 1) We scaled the feature size of nanoperforated graphene down from 18 nm at the project onset to 14 nm and then ~7.5 nm using the BCP poly(styrene-block-methyl methacrylate). The reduction in feature size was enabled by a novel patterning strategy that employs a dual hard and soft buffer layer between the graphene and the BCP to maximize etching-control and facilitate the removal of processing materials.

 2) We conducted fundamental measurements of electrical conduction through these nanoperforated membranes and systematically correlated their properties with feature size for the first time.

 3) We developed a high throughput and high fidelity route to form BCP templates on graphene by first assembling the templates on another substrate and then transferring them onto the graphene. This route is generally applicable to many possible materials, not just graphene.

 4) We advanced the manufacturing of graphene nanoribbons and graphene nanotubes, as well. Similar BCP-based approaches were developing for fabricating nanoribbons. For manufacturing nanotubes, a different strategy was needed. When graphene nanotubes (also called carbon nanotubes) are synthesized, they first exist as solid powders, which are then purified and dispersed into liquid inks. One roadblock with nanotubes has been assembling them from these inks onto substrates as aligned arrays. In this project, we discovered a highly effective method for depositing nanotubes onto substrates into aligned arrays, called floating evaporative self-assembly (FESA).
